body: sorry for spamming the pull request section with bad requests. i will try to keep it more tidy the next time.

yes, you are right. non western characters like æ—¥æœ¬ are not read correctly, but neither they are without this patch or with windows-1252 encoding. i must admit, that this topic is not closed by this patch and needs more attention for non western characters, but at least the scanning process of the filesystem now works and is not aborted by special (western) characters like ã© or ã¤ when using a windows system as the server.
using com, like in https://gist.github.com/2665437 is probably the only viable solution for now.
i agree, but i am still reluctant to accept the patch. it hides the problem further (i.e. hides in more 'edge cases' from a western pov, and only fixes it for a tiny use case.

yes, i see your point. i agree with you to not accept the patch, as it does not cover the problem completely. i will look for a better solution for it. anyhow it would be great if this topic is not forgotten, as it may also affect other users.
@raimund-schluessler any news on this? thx

@danimo shall we take over this pr?
due to it's dead status i'd close it, but i think it has too much value to be thrown away.
what do you mean 'take over'? merge? then no.
'to take over' -> ã¼bernehmen ;-)

sorry i haven't said anything yet. lot to do recently. i am still working on this and it seems like the com scripting danimo proposed may work. but it will take me some more time. so maybe close this pr and i will try to resubmit a better solution. regards.

@raimund-schluessler thanks for getting back to us! 
i'm looking forward to your next pr.

@raimund-schluessler ping ;-)

any news on this? looks like the user base using windows server is increasing - we'd love to see this fixed!
feel free to let us know if we can support you.
thx.

well, news yes, but no good ones. i had a look at the com scripting and found that it sometimes works. no changes on the script, just a site reload and sometimes all files are listed correctly (also with special characters) but most of the time they don't get listed. i have no idea why this happens or how to fix it and it is not predictable for me what the script will do after the next reload.
however, i think com scripting is not the best solution anyway, as it may not be available by default (as on my machine) and therefore is no universal solution.

furthermore it does not address the actual problem, which is the lack of unicode support for the file system functions of php on windows machines.
i found a blog discussion where one commenter said, that the wrong version of the win 32 api (ansi) and not the unicode version are used by default in php: http://www.rooftopsolutions.nl/blog/filesystem-encoding-and-php
he claimed, that you would just need to compile php with the correct flags, but as this by far exceeds my coding skills (not familiar with c/c++) i can't tell, whether this is correct or not.

i must admit, that i have stopped looking for a solution for this problem for now. as i am not absolutely relying on windows i will give debian a look the next time. sorry i can't help here anymore.

thanks a lot for getting back to us!

hmm - is your com-based approach publicly available? (e.g. on you github fork?)
i'd like to have a look.

thx

i have created a very small test case (basically just testing the winfsutf8 file of nicolas grekas with different file names). you can find it under: https://github.com/raimund-schluessler/php-com-scripting

please note, that when downloading the files by zip, the file names are corrupted. i don't know, if they are correct when using git itself. oc is obviously not the only one struggeling with encoding. however, the file names are shown correctly in the webinterface. i attached a pdf of the output on my machine. some files were readable by com, which were not with standard php. other filenames were not readable at all, although the windows short path generated by com is valid.

dear all,

i've read lots and lots of comments about the filename issue on windows the last 2 days, as i'm also affected. i'd love to use owncloud on my server, but the filename issue blocks me. also the issue breaks webdav for filenames with "umlauts" for the uploading direction.

i've also read the article about "wrong php compilation" on windows, but i was not able to find a proper php version to try (and i'm also not in the knowledge to compile my own one).

however, pointing to errors of php may only be half the truth. i've put ajaxplorer on the same machine with the same php on the same iis - and it's working perfectly with all special chars in filenames! so there must be a way to have it working also on windows.

i'm not the biggest fan of windows for servers, but i have the need to use it, and i won't put a second machine as an "owncloud" server beside.

any idea of a fix? ;-)
@jacotec thanks for the hint to ajaxplorer - i'll have a look at their code basis

@deepdiver1975 
anytime.

unfortunately my knowledge is on embedded systems, so i can't really help. but i'd like to test anything as my oc implementation is just waiting for this fix ...

also ajaxplorer is multi-os ... not especially designed for windows and no special windows version.

i had a quick look at ajaxplorer - they convert all filenames to the encoding of the operation system.
key class is http://ajaxplorer.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/ajaxplorer/trunk/core/src/core/classes/class.systemtextencoding.php?revision=3378&content-type=text%2fplain

i need to think about this if it helps us here as well .......

i think this solution has the same problems as my initial pull request (although it is indeed better to use the encoding of the operating system, instead some pre-choosen encoding).

it will improve the situation for some users, as it will be more likely, that the characters they are used to will work with oc. but it is no general solution as not all unicode characters are supported. when i try to create a file with name "japan-æ—¥æœ¬.txt", it fails because "æ—¥æœ¬" is not supported by my system encoding. on the other hand "ã¤", "ã¶" ,"ã¼" and "ãÿ" work now.

@jacotec it will work with german umlauts, but will certainly break with anything that's not available in the local character set. plus the iso latin1 and windows ansi mapping are not 100% compatible. you are not asking for a workaround here, you are asking for moving trouble elsewhere.

well, i am using it on my server, but with oc 4.5.3 (i hadn't had time to upgrade yet and may switch to linux anyway). scanning a folder with ~20.000 files, several of them with "ã¤ã¶ã¼ãÿ" in the file names, was not a problem. the drawback is, that filenames with characters not in the choosen encoding can not be scanned and found. as danimo said it is not really a workaround, but it moves the troubles to a region where they don't bother me at the moment. i won't recommend here to use it for you, as it is a really quick and dirty solution and may cause troubles i can't overlook. but for me it is the only possibility to work with such files at the moment. if you want to test it i will adapt it for oc 4.5.5, but you have to be clear, that it is rather untested and experimental.

with the current state of my analysis i can only say: 4.5.x will not work properly on windows servers.

whatever solution we will choose it will arrive with oc5 and i doubt that we can backport it to 4.5.x

sorry guys but i see no other solution at the moment: if you want to use owncloud productive please use a linux server.

@karlitschek we need to talk ;-)

@deepdiver1975 
so this problem is definitely on the roadmap for oc5? if it's just that few weeks, i can wait for it. i've tired out raimund's patch in 4.5.5 and it's working, but as i understand you, i'll risk breaking something with oc5 then?
@jacotec the risk will be that once there i proper handling for it, it will fail with the broken filenames potentially still produced by that patch.

@jacotec 
i cannot promise if this will be fixed for oc5 - we are discussing and negotiating this. thx
